[2025-06-07T01:03:11] 'lekrsu': Faster reduction of phase as phase voltage increases (speed, if you want to call it so)
[2025-06-07T01:03:11] Gt Pro Karl: It's peaking at almost 400amps total
[2025-06-07T01:04:02] 'lekrsu': Approximately: 50A batt at full speed = 50A phase.
[2025-06-07T01:04:17] Gt Pro Karl: So increasing battery amps will keep me from losing speed faster
[2025-06-07T01:05:28] 'lekrsu': You see on the RT screen during riding, beginning at 200A with a very quick reduction down until it eventually hits 50A. You're adding field weakening so it won't be exactly this now.
[2025-06-07T01:06:26] 'lekrsu': Phase current is your acceleration power.
[2025-06-07T01:06:41] 'lekrsu': Does it make sense?
[2025-06-07T01:07:05] Gt Pro Karl: Yes but the field weakening is making me faster?
[2025-06-07T01:07:10] Gt Pro Karl: As well?
[2025-06-07T01:07:17] 'lekrsu': Don't confuse speed with acceleration.
[2025-06-07T01:07:37] Gt Pro Karl: Ahhh
[2025-06-07T01:08:06] Gt Pro Karl: So 210 amps is faster acceleration
[2025-06-07T01:08:15] Gt Pro Karl: Battery and field weakening affect speed
[2025-06-07T01:08:42] 'lekrsu': You can be speed limited by battery amps not being able to generate the power you need.
[2025-06-07T01:09:15] 'lekrsu': Increasing battery current will increase your phase current between the span of standstill and top speed, to be higher at any speed.
[2025-06-07T01:09:53] Gt Pro Karl: No we are getting somewhere! Thankyou so much guys!
[2025-06-07T01:11:34] 'lekrsu': <photos/photo_23835@07-06-2025_01-11-34.jpg>

[2025-06-07T21:07:05] Matthew: So the experience with him. I was building the ninebot g30lp for him. I figured if it works for him there would be no issues for me as im ~190lbs. So the g30lp was fine with him. I even upgraded to 52v on a stock motor for him. We ended up getting him a tiny and light amazon volpram or whatever brand it carried him around fine. But if you have hills and like a 500watts max motor then you may overheat it. But if its like a 1000+ watts motor then you vaguely dont need to worry about things. Only time we worried about the motor too hot was going into field weakening and 40mph. Could do that regularly but not nonstop. I swear most these motors are all happy until you want to cruise 40mph. They just seem to slowly heatsoak. If youre really worried about it statorade is a very good product to thing about using.

[2025-06-10T11:29:48] Aviv Turg: <photos/photo_23924@10-06-2025_11-29-48.jpg>

[2025-06-10T13:49:28] Smart Repair: A lot also depends on the cooling. With very good cooling alone, you can achieve at least twice the performance compared to if the ESC is loose. I've also seen people simply glue their controllers to the frame without removing the paint, etc., and then they wonder why their system constantly crashes.
[2025-06-10T13:50:41] Smart Repair: with 26s I haven't managed to get to 95% yet ğŸ˜…
[2025-06-10T13:51:45] Marius: Yep all depends on how Regularly u drive top speed
[2025-06-10T13:55:16] Smart Repair: And that depends on the motor ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸ It's simply impossible to make a reliable general statement. How much current you can push through the ubox depends on too many factors. It does make a difference whether you're constantly driving at 120 km/h with a 17x4 and 60A fw, or a 33x2 without fw.
[2025-06-10T13:55:49] Smart Repair: what are your maximum values for the 250/240, I would also be interested
[2025-06-10T14:01:47] Smart Repair: What would also be cool is a list of battery, ESC, and motor data, such as maximum speed at a certain amount of current. Basically, a list where everyone can enter their setup. Anyone interested in something like that?

[2025-06-14T23:04:27] Matthew: So for detection for the motors should run on vesc tool. Go to setup wizard
[2025-06-14T23:04:41] Matthew: Setup motors click
[2025-06-14T23:04:43] Dualtron Achilleus: You can already do it by register real data from vesc
[2025-06-14T23:05:00] Dualtron Achilleus: If speed is correct
[2025-06-14T23:05:23] Matthew: Use generic direct drive. Use large outrunner for the type of motor
[2025-06-14T23:08:23] Matthew: Click run or detect i forget specific and make sure your motors are secured and off the ground or anything touching the wheels because the setup wizard is going to make the motors spin to detect what it needs to. Once detection is finished theres a tab to select for fwd motor movement and click that and make sure motors are spinning correct direction. You may need to invert directions to have proper forward rotation

[2025-06-15T22:29:11] Matthew: From people here and my own experience spintend has been good and I recommend their stuff. Their customer support is good too. If you want controllers you won't outgrow i recommend the 85250 and you would need 2 of them. But for space reasons and also reasons the the 85150 can produce some amazing numbers. These guys got some crazy power but for my experience 50 battery per motor on 85150 and vsett 10 motors was wild. I was getting around 10kw @ 18s

[2025-06-17T15:20:35] Matthew: On the side bar. When in motor configuration. Click read, change value you want. After you change a value you need to hit write for the change to be programmed. The M with an arrow pointing down is the motor configuration write. Bottom right corner will confirm motor configuration or app configuration write successful i do believe are the terms. The letter A with downward arrow is for the app configurations. Same here as with motor configurations click read, change the value and then click the letter A with a downward pointing arrow.

[2025-06-17T16:04:41] Matthew: Yeah, you need to make sure you click write after the value is changed. Default just let's you know Default. For current settings programmed click read, then change the value then click write. The M is for the motor configurations. When you go to app configuration it is basically same as for motor configurations. You can see value programmed, Default, and write but with the icons with arrow Labeled A downward facing arrow is write.

[2025-06-18T00:35:15] 'lekrsu': Very space & weight inefficient 500wh on steering pole.
[2025-06-18T00:36:04] cihan: Having lots of free space inside deck will be really beneficial for me. I think about having a big battery like 18s10p. [2025-06-18T00:36:56] cihan: That's what I'm concerned about. I think it will be better if I can somehow add a rack on top of rear wheel and place the battery there.
[2025-06-18T00:37:24] 'lekrsu': It doesn't. Use a BMS with common charge/discharge.
[2025-06-18T00:38:23] 'lekrsu': JBD/ANT/JK all does unified. So does Ninebot on "discharge" port.
[2025-06-18T00:38:56] 'lekrsu': Charge port? More like all port.
[2025-06-18T00:41:34] cihan: I'll check. I have one big JK BMS already which was too big to fit inside the deck. Do you use one BMS or 2 BMS for each battery connected parallel?
[2025-06-18T00:41:53] 'lekrsu': Always one bms per battery. So two in your case.
[2025-06-18T00:42:31] cihan: Do those BMS communicate with each other or work completely individually?
[2025-06-18T00:42:47] 'lekrsu': Physics takes care of the equalization.
[2025-06-18T00:42:56] 'lekrsu': Just needs to be connected at the same voltage.
[2025-06-18T00:44:32] 'lekrsu': 20S + 20S in parallel means two individual paths of current to discharge from, both working together, optimally never disconnected. 10S + 10S (per example) in series means a not self equalized voltage on both, needing two separate 10S chargers, and your wiring is longer.
[2025-06-18T00:45:59] 'lekrsu': Would only add another battery in series, of equal capacity and current capabilities, if the internal battery is already done and won't be re-done.
[2025-06-18T00:46:36] cihan: Don't you use ideal diode module for parallel batteries?
[2025-06-18T00:46:54] 'lekrsu': You don't need any hardware do put batteries in parallel
[2025-06-18T00:48:27] cihan: By the way I should read the pdf shared here by Francois, there's lots of information there.
[2025-06-18T00:49:19] cihan: But what if when batteries are discharged to different voltage levels? One of them will have higher voltage than the other and the one will higher voltage will start charging the other one.
[2025-06-18T00:49:53] 'lekrsu': It'll charge the other as fast as the resistance of wiring allows and enter short protection. Without a bms it'd be a likely fire risk.
[2025-06-18T00:52:06] cihan: Don't you need to reset BMS when it enters short protection? What happens when this happens during riding?
[2025-06-18T00:52:41] 'lekrsu': Won't ever normally happen unless battery malfunctions if connected initially at the same voltage.
[2025-06-18T00:53:01] 'lekrsu': Most good boards have Bluetooth apps to reset through.
[2025-06-18T00:56:46] cihan: I'm thinking about a scenario like this. Internal battery is 10s4p. And I'll connect an external battery which is 10s10p. External battery will have less resistance and supply more current during high power demand. However when I end climbing a hill and come to flat ground again I'll draw less power and the bigger external battery will probably still have higher voltage than the internal battery. Or voltage drop on the external battery will be low during climbing and external battery will start charging internal battery. Doesn't it ever happen?
[2025-06-18T00:58:04] cihan: On the other hand I don't know if I can completely rely on BMS without any other protection.
[2025-06-18T00:58:40] 'lekrsu': What else would you rely on if not a BMS?
[2025-06-18T00:59:26] 'lekrsu': Fuse is like a BMS but travel back a hundred years of technology advance.
[2025-06-18T01:02:48] cihan: Ä°deal diode seems like a great protection to me not allowing batteries charge each other. Maybe I can add a fuse too. Is it unnecessary to add another fuse?
[2025-06-18T01:06:07] 'lekrsu': You need them to charge each other to be in parallel. All to have unified ground throughout.
[2025-06-18T01:11:29] haku: https://youtube.com/shorts/kWDVe6ke7Qc?si=tIImdDOXYBeuHpIZ
[2025-06-18T01:11:55] cihan: So do you limit charging current on the BMS? Does BMS allow switching between charging and discharging state fast enough?
[2025-06-18T01:12:20] 'lekrsu': Yes, they do switch between faster than you can fathom. Or one may even just call it simultaneous. You can charge and discharge at the same instance.
[2025-06-18T01:14:20] 'lekrsu': You can't decrease charging current, only out a dead stop max limit and you want the limit to be something you never reach.
[2025-06-18T01:16:33] Crazy scoots: <video_file>
[2025-06-18T01:16:56] 'lekrsu': I'm sure the difference in battery resistance helps to reduce the mismatch draw to some degree.
[2025-06-18T01:17:12] cihan: That's great. I'll also need regen so I need to allow BMS have high enough charge current limit. I think voltage imbalance during ride will be small and will never ever need such high charge current as the regen needs. I think about an alternative for regen braking. I don't want to charge battery with such high current even for short times. Can I add a big power resistor or somehow use the chassis of the scooter as a resistor for regen? What do you think?
[2025-06-18T01:17:55] 'lekrsu': No, no resistors. You set the charging current in your VESC.
[2025-06-18T01:18:06] 'lekrsu': Set 10A and it'll do 10A.
[2025-06-18T01:18:29] cihan: Somehow I'll try to make batteries have similar resistance. External battery will have longer path to the motor so even if the external battery has less resistance inside, cable resistance will add to it.
[2025-06-18T01:20:16] cihan: Is there anyway to monitor and save charge /discharge currents with smart BMS with Bluetooth connection so I can see how things worked and if there was something wrong after a ride?
[2025-06-18T01:20:59] 'lekrsu': Depends on the BMS, JBD has graphs if you stay connected with app open, afaik. Haven't tried it.
[2025-06-18T01:22:09] cihan: OK, I'll check it. Thank you so much for all the answers, it was really enlightening.

[2025-06-20T00:48:50] cihan: I would like to have opinions on a parallel battery design. Internal battery will be at C capacity. External battery will be at 2C capacity, voltages will be same when connecting them if it matters . I'll disable charging of internal battery at BMS and optionally add an ideal diode to output of internal battery to prevent back flow. I'll enable charging on external battery for regen so regen current will flow completely to external battery. External battery will always have higher current than the internal battery and internal battery will never be able to charge external battery. Could there be any problems during ride? Will this make riding jerky since internal battery will start supplying current suddenly when external battery voltage drops to the same level of internal battery?

[2025-06-22T15:42:59] Anthony Meza: Positive Ramping Time in vesc_tool is the amount of time it takes to smoothly transition from zero throttle to full throttle. It acts like a filter on your throttle input, preventing sudden jumps and delivering a gradual increase in motor power. .30 seems to give you a snappy lil pull. What version are you on?

[2025-06-22T20:49:06] Matthew: Xt90 handles 100amps no issues but not for a long extended period of time. The xt90 connector normally just have 10-60amps running through them regularly for a scooter so a burst of 100 amps with proper wire gauge and soldering job 10-20 seconds of 100amps is fine. Going over 120amps I would do xt150 or qs8 or similar

[2025-06-24T12:40:27] S1m 0n: Correct. On my first try i added to much. The motor was overheating. Just a little bit, something as thick as 3-4 hairs between the magnets is perfectly sufficient.
[2025-06-24T12:41:20] S1m 0n: but if the engine gets too hot, it dries out anyway.. it doesn't do as much as you'd expect from it, in my experience
[2025-06-24T12:44:23] Arnau Martinez Casals: I told you haha
[2025-06-24T12:47:31] S1m 0n: Which settings can I test for more torque? I'm using a Kaabo Mantis 10 single motor with 45H magnets and a Makerbase 84100hp. 55A battery current, 90A phase current, speed ramp 0.11, and expo throttle +30%. I'm happy with it. I'm faster, sportier and more efficient than with the original controller (+ShuntMod to 35A) But when starting uphill, it feels weak. The speed only increases very slowly. It was different with the original controller... it just kept going uphill, too.
[2025-06-24T12:49:26] S1m 0n: I also set it to "sensored" up to around 20 km/h. This made a small improvement, but it was still far from the original controller.
[2025-06-24T12:57:53] Paolo â­: Of course, original controller is set to 150A phaseï¼Œyou can get same performance if you change phase current

[2025-06-25T20:17:12] cihan: I'm asking for opinion if I should regrease the headset bearing or not. I used to apply carbon paste on the fork tube where folding clamp holds it since the folding clamp was slipping on the fork tube. Carbon paste really works and it's great. However I accidentally put little amount of carbon paste on the headset bearing too. Now stem right /left movement is really stiff and I find myself leaning more when turning. Do you think I should clean headset bearing and regrease or continue as it is now? By the way I liked how front wheel firms more rigid when turning but I somehow feel I need to balance the scooter often with my body more often now. I recommend carbon paste (I bought Motorex brand if it makes sense) to anyone who has such issues. I was going to apply weakest Loctite retaining compound if carbon paste didn't work which is still too strong to dismantle later on.
[2025-06-25T20:46:34] ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸AYO#74ğŸ: I would change everything, put in new bearings.

[2025-06-27T12:36:19] ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸AYO#74ğŸ: It will lower the temperature in general, but we are only stipulating the temperature. You have to control it, but it is easy to know where you live. Go up and down the longest hill 2 or 3 times, then touch the engine with your hand. If you can't leave your hand on it for about 10 seconds, I would lower the phase a little. Some say that the engine can reach 100 degrees, but I don't trust it. I prefer to run it colder, to be honest.

[2025-07-01T11:15:49] Yamal: What I mean is, Nami users have their electronics very exposed. It's clear that we're not going to ride e-scooters when it's raining, but you never know if you might get caught in a drizzle, step in a puddle or ride on dirt tracks. In short, it's good to have it insulated. Currently, after the last Ubox breakdown, I absolutely don't step on a sandy track and I'm always aware of the water.

[2025-07-02T07:51:40] cihan: I recommend sintered metal brake pads to anyone desiring the same stopping force with less pressure on disc. Ninebot f2 pro has wobble problem when braking and it's reduced a lot with sintered brake pads and cheap (probably softer metal) disc rotor. I guess sintered brake pad had higher friction with a cheap soft metal disc rotor compared to higher quality harder metal rotor. I feel the same when sharpening knives. Softer metal cheap knives always have higher friction between the sharpening tool. Braking feel is different compared to semi metallic brake pads. Light braking has almost no effect but harder braking instantly increases braking power after 1/2 turns when pad and rotor gets warmer probably. I also like the sound of the brake and feel how pads are eating away the rotor. I don't care about the rotor since each 120 mm rotor costs me 2 USD from Temu. I guess I've solved the wobble problem when braking forever and feeling happy.)
[2025-07-02T07:55:36] cihan: Now the brake has Voith retarder like sound which I always enjoyed during bus trips.)

[2025-07-04T19:17:28] Matthew: Most people in here are using spintend products. Flipsky is more hit or miss with their poor quality control. But someone else can correct me if I'm wrong. For 72v(20s) you would need spintend higher voltage controllers. They have 3 different models 85v controllers max and there is a 100/100 alu lite model and i suggest not getting the 100/100 as its decent for lower power builds and it is super small so if space is an issue then it can be and option for lower power but people definitely recommend 85150 ubox over the 100/100 lite.. 1 model is 85250 ubox single. 85240 ubox single. 85150 ubox single. The 85150 ubox is a stout controller for its size. People are pushing 13kw on 72v and the controllers are significantly smaller than 85250/240 so you have more options for installation space. I have not used this other adc3 device but it is supposed to allow more accessories and extra function capabilities.
[2025-07-04T19:19:25] Matthew: There's this dedicated dual controller but max voltage is 18s. But it has all the other adc3 add on device capabilities. The guys say its a dated controller but still good. Youre also limited to 100amps per motor.
[2025-07-04T19:21:03] Matthew: This guy here is a ripper. People are pushing ~13kw @72v per controller.... so unless you want more power than that this controller is the one I like the most. 85250 is obviously a stout controller but its giant compared to 85150.
[2025-07-04T19:23:26] Matthew: This is device to add on to the 85250/240/150. As far as I understand that device will basically have the capabilities that the 75100 dual controller has. Or there's the option of getting a stepdown converter to 12v. I got a 20amps 12v stepdown converter for my build and am going to try it out today I think.

[2025-07-05T20:28:03] 'lekrsu': Just less copper overall, less torque.

[2025-07-09T04:33:22] Matthew: I've had a few. Im building now on a ninebot max g30p. I have a g30lp thats been a disastrous test-bed over the past year or so. Newb type disastrous. I had a single and also dual motor setup with vsett 10+ motors on 85150. 1 controller fried on me and I bricked the other one months later. Was using 85150 for a while with a lonnyo 65h 22x3 motor. Had 18s until I ruined external pack. So 16s all this year. Now a few months ago grabbed me a 65h 17x4 motor. I have no interest in going over 50mph on these escooters... put the power and more in a caged gokart and sign me up but otherwise 55mph is about my nope speed. I now have 85250 and a 100/100 lite. [2025-07-18T12:04:08] Face de Pin SucÃ©: those are the ones from LY factory We stopped making our rims long time ago there because of bad machining precision, many rims have the defect of having the holes for the mounting on motor not perfectly centered in diameter, bringing small movement and vibrations. At high speed it's annoying. Not all rims, but too many for our quality standards. Also, they don't have the tire bead seat in the rim. So basically it's a "bad rim" And even more, you have the fully standards ones, so you have to remove the brake disc if you want to remove the whole rim, they are inverted, it's a non-sense

[2025-07-18T18:30:31] Matthew: I am close on my lp. Its not really going to look any different... just gonna get accessories like headlight, horn, brake and turn signals. And last but not necessary is getting a 6s external pack to help out the 100/100 65h 17x4 with a bit more acceleration and higher top speed without fw
[2025-07-18T18:55:30] Matthew: Really won't look much different at all. So far happy now with all the components onto the scooter. Just need to run some lines from my bus bars on the 12v stepdown converter for the accessories. So ninebot max g30lp 100/100 single ubox. 14s 20ah battery running 40amps battery and 100amps phase and fw at 20amps at 85%. Lonnyo 65h 17x4 single motor with statorade. Monorim v4 front suspension and since I had extra forks laying around from a kit I bought for parts that I just did a double laminate type setup so there is really not much flex at all in the front. Aoy-36rc 165mm front shock. Ulip generic rear suspension with 291r coil-over 150mm with 450lbs spring. Skateboard deck tape cut by hand, if you look close its definitely not perfect. Watercooled system made by myself to keep vesc cool. Vesc does not overheat at all. 140mm brake rotors. Monorim non hydraulic front disc brake. Rear only using regen rn but when I get a paycheck ill be able to buy a generic bracket to bolt on a basic disc setup. Motorcycle handlebar 26" length. Locking blue handles. There's a scooter installed lightbar and on the handlebar theres another rechargeable lightbar thats pretty frickin bright. Vsett front motor is my rim for now since I can't seem to put the mantis rim back together so I just threw it in the trash. Tire on it is 11inch offroad in the front and basic 10x3 rear tire. Segway ninebot seat and case setup that ali had for $60 and not advertised full price of $160. Luggage rack rated 50lbs. Generic scooter trunk that has expansion foam layer over the bottom half and plasti-dip coated. The foam has a cut out area that holds a battery pack. It has the 14s battery sitting in there but the space cut out will also fit my yume 60v pack. There's actually enough room in that trunk to fit both the 14s and 16s on top of each other so if I need extra distance its easy to just throw a battery in there. Shock absorbing/floating cellphone holder. Cable brake handles from generic budget scooter that has hall sensors so regen brake is variable. So thats basically that full build as it sits now which i just finished this week.

[2025-07-27T20:44:33] K3BAB: VESC-Express Module (rESCue S3) This module features an ESP32-S3 microcontroller (Lolin S3), which is significantly more powerful than the original. The module allows you to connect a VESC to the VESC-Express via CAN bus, making it accessible via Bluetooth Low Energy or Wi-Fi. The module is compatible with all common Android and iOS apps (VESC Tool, Truely Yours, etc.) and comes pre-installed, making it ready for immediate use and easy to configure using the VESC Tool. The VESC-Express module can also be used to control LEDs or connect/operate a Bluetooth remote control. price 20â‚¬

[2025-08-02T06:22:26] Matthew: No, you just need to work with gravity. Flicking or tapping the brake line helps move tiny air bubbles up. And for the handle you want it level mainly to fill it completely with zero air bubbles and then close the screw on the handle and it should be good. Sometimes theres still some remaining bubbles that just you need to repeat the procedure and hopefully 2nd time is good.
[2025-08-02T06:27:38] Matthew: Someone told me theyre running 135amps max phase and absolute is 180amps phase. I have mine set at 130amps phase and 150abs. I am running 85 or 90 battery and temps for vesc are staying good. This person has been running their setup for like 8 months almost daily and they told me they are good. This is my first 100/100 so thats why I am sharing more, also because it seems almost no one buys the 100/100 because they mainly all want high power. The purpose i built the g30lp to is good and it goes up hills i want. With it having a rear suspension i dony really trust going really fast like that

[2025-08-04T18:03:29] Matthew: The vesc doesn't count pole pairs. Count amount of magnets and enter that value. Lonnyo 65h motor is 30 poles. Vsett 10+ motor is 30 poles. And as someone else mentioned for the 6.5" rim is 30 pole. Then you want direct drive in the setup. Then enter the diameter of your tire. Then check GPS while riding to verify that your tire diameter is correct. Just also to know the vesc vaguely speaking doesn't care about speed unless you're trying to use traction control or set max rpm for speed. Otherwise the correct diameter helps give you correct estimates of power consumed avg and estimated range left. I keep it accurate since i depend on all the different read outs
[2025-08-04T18:10:24] Matthew: This is available but I am not sure if it requires using a dedicated dual controller combo thats 2 units in 1.
[2025-08-04T18:10:43] Matthew: I dont know if it must pair with these vesc units to work properly
